descr.p: The DOS unit gives access to some operating system calls related to files, the file system, date and time. Except for the PalmOS target, this unit is available to all supported platforms.
The unit was first written for Dos by Florian Klaempfl. It was ported to Linux by Mark May and enhanced by Michael Van Canneyt. The Amiga version was ported by Nils Sjoholm.
Under non-DOS systems, some of the functionality is lost, as it is either impossible or meaningless to implement it. Other than that, the functionality is the same for all operating systems.

Because the DOS unit is a Turbo Pascal compatibility unit, it is no longer actively developed: the interface is frozen and it is maintained only for the purpose of porting Turbo Pascal programs. For new development, it is recommended to use the sysutils unit instead.

element.name: GetMSCount
element.short: Number of milliseconds since a starting point.

descr.p: GetMSCount returns a number of milliseconds elapsed since a certain moment in time. This moment in time is implementation dependent. This function is used for timing purposes: Subtracting the results of 2 subsequent calls to this function returns the number of milliseconds elapsed between the two calls.
This call is not very reliable, it is recommended to use some system specific calls for timings.

element.name: AddDisk
element.short: Add disk definition to list if drives (Unix only)

descr.p: AddDisk adds a filename S to the internal list of disks. It is implemented for systems which do not use DOS type drive letters. This list is used to determine which disks to use in the and calls. The and functions need a file on the specified drive, since this is required for the statfs system call. The names are added sequentially. The Dos initialization code presets the first three disks to:
The first call to AddDisk will therefore add a name for the second harddisk, The second call for the third drive, and so on until 23 drives have been added (corresponding to drives 'D:' to 'Z:')

element.name: DiskFree

descr.p: DiskFree returns the number of free bytes on a disk. The parameter Drive indicates which disk should be checked. This parameter is 1 for floppy a:, 2 for floppy b:, etc. A value of 0 returns the free space on the current drive.
descr.remark: For Unices: The diskfree and disksize functions need a file on the specified drive, since this is required for the statfs system call. These filenames are set in the initialization of the Dos unit, and have been preset to :
descr.p: There is room for 1-26 drives. You can add a drive with the procedure. These settings can be coded in dos.pp, in the initialization part.

element.errors: -1 when a failure occurs, or an invalid drive number is given.

descr.p: DiskSize returns the total size (in bytes) of a disk. The parameter Drive indicates which disk should be checked. This parameter is 1 for floppy a:, 2 for floppy b:, etc. A value of 0 returns the size of the current drive.
descr.remark: For Unix only: The diskfree and disksize functions need a file on the specified drive, since this is required for the statfs system call. These filenames are set in the initialization of the Dos unit, and have been preset to :

element.name: DosExitCode
element.short: Exit code of last executed program.
element.descr: DosExitCode contains (in the low byte) the exit-code of a program executed with the Exec call.

descr.p: DosVersion returns the operating system or kernel version. The low byte contains the major version number, while the high byte contains the minor version number.
descr.remark: On systems where versions consists of more then two numbers, only the first two numbers will be returned. For example Linux version 2.1.76 will give you DosVersion 2.1. Some operating systems, such as FreeBSD, do not have system calls to return the kernel version, in that case a value of 0 will be returned.

element.name: EnvCount
element.short: Return the number of environment variables
element.descr: EnvCount returns the number of environment variables.

element.name: EnvStr
element.descr: EnvStr returns the Index-th Name=Value pair from the list of environment variables. The index of the first pair is zero.
element.errors: The length is limited to 255 characters.

element.name: Exec
element.short: Execute another program, and wait for it to finish.

descr.p: Exec executes the program in Path, with the options given by ComLine. The program name should not appear again in ComLine, it is specified in Path. Comline contains only the parameters that are passed to the program.
After the program has terminated, the procedure returns. The Exit value of the program can be consulted with the DosExitCode function.
For an example, see

element.name: FExpand
element.short: Expand a relative path to an absolute path

descr.p: FExpand takes its argument and expands it to a complete filename, i.e. a filename starting from the root directory of the current drive, prepended with the drive-letter or volume name (when supported).
descr.remark: On case sensitive file systems (such as Unix and Linux), the resulting name is left as it is, otherwise it is converted to uppercase.

element.name: FindClose
element.short: Dispose resources allocated by a / sequence.

descr.p: FindClose frees any resources associated with the search record F.
This call is needed to free any internal resources allocated by the or calls.

The Unix implementation of the Dos unit therefore keeps a table of open directories, and when the table is full, closes one of the directories, and reopens another. This system is adequate but slow if you use a lot of searchrecs.

So, to speed up the findfirst/findnext system, the FindClose call was implemented. When you don't need a searchrec any more, you can tell this to the Dos unit by issuing a FindClose call. The directory which is kept open for this searchrec is then closed, and the table slot freed.
descr.remark: It is recommended to use the Linux call Glob when looking for files on Linux.

element.name: FindFirst
element.short: Start search for one or more files.

descr.p: FindFirst searches the file specified in Path. Normal files, as well as all special files which have the attributes specified in Attr will be returned.

It returns a SearchRec record for further searching in F. Path can contain the wildcard characters ? (matches any single character) and * (matches 0 ore more arbitrary characters). In this case FindFirst will return the first file which matches the specified criteria. If DosError is different from zero, no file(s) matching the criteria was(were) found.
descr.remark: On the EMX target, you cannot issue two different FindFirst calls. That is, you must close any previous search operation with before starting a new one. Failure to do so will end in a Run-Time Error 6 (Invalid file handle)

element.name: FindNext

descr.p: FindNext takes as an argument a SearchRec from a previous FindNext call, or a FindFirst call, and tries to find another file which matches the criteria, specified in the FindFirst call. If DosError is different from zero, no more files matching the criteria were found.
For an example, see .

element.errors: DosError is used to report errors.

descr.p: FSearch searches the file Path in all directories listed in DirList. The full name of the found file is returned. DirList must be a list of directories, separated by semi-colons. When no file is found, an empty string is returned.
descr.remark: On Unix systems, DirList can also be separated by colons, as is customary on those environments.

element.name: FSplit
element.short: Split a full-path filename in parts.
element.descr: FSplit splits a full file name into 3 parts : A Path, a Name and an extension (in ext.) The extension is taken to be all letters after the last dot (.). For Dos, however, an exception is made when LFNSupport=False, then the extension is defined as all characters after the first dot.

descr.p: GetCBreak gets the status of CTRL-Break checking under Dos and Amiga. When BreakValue is false, then Dos only checks for the CTRL-Break key-press when I/O is performed. When it is set to True, then a check is done at every system call.
descr.remark: Under non-Dos and non-Amiga operating systems, BreakValue always returns True.

element.name: GetDate
element.descr: GetDate returns the system's date. Year is a number in the range 1980..2099.mday is the day of the month, wday is the day of the week, starting with Sunday as day 0.

descr.p: Getenv returns the value of the environment variable EnvVar. When there is no environment variable EnvVar defined, an empty string is returned.
descr.remark: Under some operating systems (such as Unix), case is important when looking for EnvVar.

descr.p: GetFAttr returns the file attributes of the file-variable f. F can be a untyped or typed file, or of type Text. f must have been assigned, but not opened. The attributes can be examined with the following constants :
Under Linux, supported attributes are:

ul.li: ReadOnly if the current process doesn't have access to the file.
Hidden for files whose name starts with a dot ('.').

element.name: GetFTime
element.descr: GetFTime returns the modification time of a file. This time is encoded and must be decoded with UnPackTime. F must be a file type, which has been assigned, and opened.

descr.p: GetIntVec returns the address of interrupt vector IntNo.
descr.remark: This call does nothing, it is present for compatibility only. Modern systems do not allow low level access to the hardware.

element.name: GetLongName
element.short: Get the long filename of a DOS 8.3 filename.

descr.p: This function is only implemented in the GO32V2 and Win32 versions of Free Pascal.
GetLongName changes the filename p to a long filename if the API call to do this is successful. The resulting string is the long file name corresponding to the short filename p.
The function returns True if the API call was successful, False otherwise.
This function should only be necessary when using the DOS extender under Windows 95 and higher.

element.errors: If the API call was not successful, False is returned.

element.name: GetShortName
element.short: Get the short (8.3) filename of a long filename.

descr.p: This function is only implemented in the GO32V2 and Win32 versions of Free Pascal.
GetShortName changes the filename p to a short filename if the API call to do this is successful. The resulting string is the short file name corresponding to the long filename p.
The function returns True if the API call was successful, False otherwise.
This function should only be necessary when using the DOS extender under Windows 95 and higher.

element.errors: If the API call was not successful, False is returned.

descr.p: GetTime returns the system's time. Hour is a on a 24-hour time scale. sec100 is in hundredth of a second.
descr.remark: Certain operating systems (such as Amiga), always set the sec100 field to zero.

descr.p: GetVerify returns the status of the verify flag under Dos. When Verify is True, then Dos checks data which are written to disk, by reading them after writing. If Verify is False, then data written to disk are not verified.
descr.remark: Under non-Dos systems (excluding EMX applications running under vanilla DOS), Verify is always True.

descr.p: Intr executes a software interrupt number IntNo (must be between 0 and 255), with processor registers set to Regs. After the interrupt call returned, the processor registers are saved in Regs.
descr.remark: Under non-Dos operating systems, this call does nothing.

descr.p: Keep terminates the program, but stays in memory. This is used for TSR (Terminate Stay Resident) programs which catch some interrupt. ExitCode is the same parameter as the Halt function takes.
descr.remark: This call does nothing, it is present for compatibility only.

element.name: weekday
element.short: Return the day of the week
element.descr: WeekDay returns the day of the week on which the day Y/M/D falls. Sunday is represented by 0, Saturday is 6.

element.name: DTToUnixDate
element.short: Convert a DateTime to Unix timestamp
element.descr: DTToUnixDate converts the DateTime value in DT to a Unix timestamp. It is an internal function, implemented on Unix platforms, and should not be used.

element.name: UnixDateToDT
element.short: Convert a Unix timestamp to a DateTime record
element.descr: DTToUnixDate converts the Unix timestamp value in SecsPast to a DateTime representation in DT. It is an internal function, implemented on Unix platforms, and should not be used.

descr.p: MSDos executes an operating system call. This is the same as doing a Intr call with the interrupt number for an OS call.
descr.remark: Under non-Dos operating systems, this call does nothing. On DOS systems, this calls interrupt $21.

element.name: PackTime
element.short: Pack DateTime value to a packed-time format.
element.descr: UnPackTime converts the date and time specified in T to a packed-time format which can be fed to SetFTime.

descr.p: SetCBreak sets the status of CTRL-Break checking. When BreakValue is false, then Dos only checks for the CTRL-Break key-press when I/O is performed. When it is set to True, then a check is done at every system call.
descr.remark: Under non-Dos and non-Amiga operating systems, this call does nothing.

descr.p: SetDate sets the system's internal date. Year is a number between 1980 and 2099.
descr.remark: On a Unix machine, there must be root privileges, otherwise this routine will do nothing. On other Unix systems, this call currently does nothing.

descr.p: SetFAttr sets the file attributes of the file-variable F. F can be a untyped or typed file, or of type Text. F must have been assigned, but not opened. The attributes can be a sum of the following constants:
descr.remark: Under Unix like systems (such as Linux and BeOS) the call exists, but is not implemented, i.e. it does nothing.

descr.p: SetFTime sets the modification time of a file, this time is encoded and must be encoded with PackTime. F must be a file type, which has been assigned, and opened.
descr.remark: Under Unix like systems (such as Linux and BeOS) the call exists, but is not implemented, i.e. it does nothing.

descr.p: SetIntVec sets interrupt vector IntNo to Vector. Vector should point to an interrupt procedure.
descr.remark: This call does nothing, it is present for compatibility only.

descr.p: SetTime sets the system's internal clock. The Hour parameter is on a 24-hour time scale.
descr.remark: On a Linux machine, there must be root privileges, otherwise this routine will do nothing. On other Unix systems, this call currently does nothing.

descr.p: SetVerify sets the status of the verify flag under Dos. When Verify is True, then Dos checks data which are written to disk, by reading them after writing. If Verify is False, then data written to disk are not verified.
descr.remark: Under non-Dos operating systems (excluding EMX applications running under vanilla Dos), Verify is always True.

descr.p: SwapVectors swaps the contents of the internal table of interrupt vectors with the current contents of the interrupt vectors. This is called typically in before and after an Exec call.
descr.remark: Under certain operating systems, this routine may be implemented as an empty stub.

element.name: UnPackTime
element.short: Unpack packed file time to a DateTime value

descr.p: UnPackTime converts the file-modification time in p to a DateTime record. The file-modification time can be returned by GetFTime, FindFirst or FindNext calls.
For an example, see .

element.name: SearchRec.Mode
element.descr: Mode contains the file mode as it exists in Unix systems. See the baseunix unit for more information about the mode field.
